entry.title: P0606 OBD-II code on a 2008 Toyota Camry
entry.content:
A couple of days ago I had some lights come up on the dash of my 2008 Toyota Camry. The slip indicator, VSC and Check Engine lights were on. First I did a quick check of my gas cap to see if it was sealed completely, because this is one of the common reasons why a check engine light would be on. After checking that, I went to my local AutoZone to get the code read. The code that came up was P0606: PCM/ECM Processor Fault1. The guy that helped me read my code seemed very confused as to why this code was coming up on such a new model of car. He asked if I recently installed any new stereo systems or speakers, to which I said no.

Knowingly or not, he reset the code on my car. Upon returning home to research this code further I couldn’t find anything that specific to my model car. Luckily I found this blog post from a couple Google searches. User blackx-runner described the same problem that I was having, although I didn’t notice my car reacting any different when on the road. Recently we’ve had a lot of rain here and he said that he noticed his truck getting the error after a carwash or heavy rain. I’ve had my car outside a lot so I think my issue may be related to this.

I’ll keep this blog post updated with any problems I have with this problem, but for now a simple reset seems to have fixed it.

Update 16 Oct. 2013 - Still haven’t had the problem come back. Looks like it was just a fluke.

Update 23 Dec. 2013 - Just had the error code happen again. It rained for about 2 days straight in Cleveland, I think that’s what caused it, though I can’t be sure. But this time it came with a bonus error code, P0138.

Found a couple resources online, here and here. According to the first link, the official Toyota PDF from 2008, it’s an issue that is covered under warrenty for 36 months or 36,000 miles, which I’m over both.

The second link, the ToyotaNation.com forum, user yukon700 has the same problem as me, only his car is a 2007 Camry. He says:

After researching and talking to a friend he said I should just go to autozone and replace the O2 sensor which failed due to high voltage which is behind the catalytic converter and see if that works. Toyota warns that I need to replace everything and by just replacing the one sensor it will fry again and be a waste.

I’m going to take it to my mechanic and see what he says about all of this.

  1. http://www.obd-codes.com/p0606↩
